p: Addressing this gap in knowledge is critical. Cities’ policies to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions intersect with many aspects of urban life and redistribute resources with direct and indirect consequences for vulnerable populations. There is growing evidence that urban climate actions can lead to disparities in energy access and pricing9,33,34, inequitable access to clean technologies9,34,35 and low-carbon transportation36,37, unequally distributed employment opportunities9,20,38 and green gentrification36,39. Urban scholars and decision-makers could therefore benefit from understanding how different cities conceptualize the justice implications of climate mitigation policies and identifying the policy tools that have been developed to address these complex issues in urban areas.
